#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHANGES AT FORLORN RIVER
#Text=THE first of March saw the federal occupation of the garrison at Casita .
#Text=After a short , decisive engagement the rebels were dispersed into small bands and driven eastward along the boundary line toward Nogales .
#Text=It was the destiny of Forlorn River , however , never to return to the slow , sleepy tenor of its former existence .
#Text=Belding 's predictions came true .
#Text=That straggling line of home-seekers was but a forerunner of the real invasion of Altar Valley .

#Text=Refugees from Mexico and from Casita spread the word that water and wood and grass and land were to be had at Forlorn River ; and as if by magic the white tents and red adobe houses sprang up to glisten in the sun .
#Text=Belding was happier than he had been for a long time .
#Text=He believed that evil days for Forlorn River , along with the apathy and lack of enterprise , were in the past .
#Text=He hired a couple of trustworthy Mexicans to ride the boundary line , and he settled down to think of ranching and irrigation and mining projects .
#Text=Every morning he expected to receive some word form Sonoyta or Yuma , telling him that Yaqui had guided his party safely across the desert .
#Text=Belding was simple-minded , a man more inclined to action than reflection .
#Text=When the complexities of life hemmed him in , he groped his way out , never quite understanding .
#Text=His wife had always been a mystery to him .
#Text=Nell was sunshine most of the time , but , like the sun-dominated desert , she was subject to strange changes , wilful , stormy , sudden .
#Text=It was enough for Belding now to find his wife in a lighter , happier mood , and to see Nell dreamily turning a ring round and round the third finger of her left hand and watching the west .
#Text=Every day both mother and daughter appeared farther removed from the past darkly threatening days .
#Text=Belding was hearty in his affections , but undemonstrative .
#Text=If there was any sentiment in his make-up it had an outlet in his memory of Blanco Diablo and a longing to see him .
#Text=Often Belding stopped his work to gaze out over the desert toward the west .
#Text=When he thought of his rangers and Thorne and Mercedes he certainly never forgot his horse .
#Text=He wondered if Diablo was running , walking , resting ; if Yaqui was finding water and grass .
#Text=In March , with the short desert winter over , the days began to grow warm .
#Text=The noon hours were hot , and seemed to give promise of the white summer blaze and blasting furnace wind soon to come .
#Text=No word was received from the rangers .
#Text=But this caused Belding no concern , and it seemed to him that his women folk considered no news good news .
#Text=Among the many changes coming to pass in Forlorn River were the installing of post-office service and the building of a mescal drinking-house .
#Text=Belding had worked hard for the post office , but he did not like the idea of a saloon for Forlorn River .
#Text=Still , that was an inevitable evil .
#Text=The Mexicans would have mescal .
#Text=Belding had kept the little border hamlet free of an establishment for distillation of the fiery cactus drink .

#Text=A good many Americans drifted into Forlorn River -- miners , cowboys , prospectors , outlaws , and others of nondescript character ; and these men , of course , made the saloon , which was also an inn , their headquarters .
#Text=Belding , with Carter and other old residents , saw the need of a sheriff for Forlorn River .
#Text=One morning early in this spring month , while Belding was on his way from the house to the corrals , he saw Nell running Blanco Jose down the road at a gait that amazed him .
#Text=She did not take the turn of the road to come in by the gate .
#Text=She put Jose at a four-foot wire fence , and came clattering into the yard .
#Text=" Nell must have another tantrum , " said Belding .
#Text=" She 's long past due . "
#Text=Blanco Jose , like the other white horses , was big of frame and heavy , and thunder rolled from under his great hoofs .
#Text=Nell pulled him up , and as he pounded and slid to a halt in a cloud of dust she swung lightly down .
#Text=It did not take more than half an eye for Belding to see that she was furious .
#Text=" Nell , what 's come off now ? " asked Belding .
#Text=" I 'm not going to tell you , " she replied , and started away , leading Jose toward the corral .
#Text=Belding leisurely followed .
#Text=She went into the corral , removed Jose 's bridle , and led him to the watering-trough .
#Text=Belding came up , and without saying anything began to unbuckle Jose 's saddle girths .
#Text=But he ventured a look at Nell .
#Text=The red had gone from her face , and he was surprised to see her eyes brimming with tears .
#Text=Most assuredly this was not one of Nell 's tantrums .
#Text=While taking off Jose 's saddle and hanging it in the shed Belding pondered in his slow way .
#Text=When he came back to the corral Nell had her face against the bars , and she was crying .
#Text=He slipped a big arm around her and waited .
#Text=Although it was not often expressed , there was a strong attachment between them .
#Text=" Dad , I do n't want you to think me a -- a baby any more , " she said .
#Text=" I 've been insulted . "
#Text=With a specific fact to make clear thought in Belding 's mind he was never slow .
#Text=" I knew something unusual had come off .
